properties.name: A quick breakfast before Costco
properties.description: Posted by Ourfounder This morning we needed to go to Costco, which is always a sort of an exercise in public humiliation and an utter loss of self. So to prepare, we went to 663 Cafe and had a hearty Chinese lunch at breakfast time. So we had their Siu Yoch, Pepper Salt Eggplant and some Gai Lan. 663 (lok lok sam) is one of the better Seattle honger restaurants. The Siu Yoch is actually pretty good. And that\'s the only good Siu Yoch you can get here. Siu Yoch is like bacon, pork rinds, and pork all in one nice little crunch, chewy, dry and juicy package. It could very well be natures most perfect food.

properties.name: Chiang's Gourmet: Zach's Birthday Dinner
properties.description: Posted by OurfounderWe have gone to Chiang\'s several times now with Zach. Tonight we loaded up on Zach\'s favorites. He was the only one to touch the menu. I\'m going to wait to put in what we had ... Zach is sending me pictures.

properties.name: Chocolate Reaches its Target!
properties.description: Posted by OurfounderI\'ll have photos for this when we get back to Seattle. I just wanted to note that we dropped off much of Vivian\'s Chocolate to The Cellar Wine Shoppe. Of course it was well received. Vivian has put in a lot of work this week getting the delivery ready. We have about 100 chocolates left over from the whole experience. She\'s learned a lot about production rates, appropriate chocolate molds, hand rolling, ganache stabilization, and decorating. Well, she already knew most of it but now she knows it faster!

properties.description: Posted by Johndoe

properties.name: Fran's Chocolates
properties.description: Posted by Choconancy2626 N.E. University Village Street, Seattle, WA 98105Since 1982, Fran Bigelow has made wonderful chocolates.

properties.name: I Like Susan Mainzer: Dinner at Lucques
properties.description: Posted by Ourfounder8474 Melrose Ave, West Hollywood, CAMy lifelong friend John\'s girlfriend / house shopping buddy was told that I like food. And Susan knows Los Angeles like you wouldn\'t believe. So John told her that I like good food. Bless her heart, she took me to the West Hollywood Foodie Altar of Lucques on a Sunday night. In the image below we see Susan lurking in the shadows (she\'s kinda a behind-the-scenes type) of my dessert crepes. I have eaten all over the world and there are three restaurants that stand head and shoulders above everything else for outright technique. I have been to many other restaurants that had vibrant flavors that blew me away, but this is my top three technique list: These were: 1. Cafe Nora in Washington DC 2. Le Crocodile in Vancouver BC and now Lucques. We went on Sunday, so we had the Sunday dinner (see the web site). I had the mussels. They were delicious, the sauce and the white beans went perfectly with the mussels. But the real technique was shown in the rillettes. The duck in the rillettes was perfectly fibrous, the accompanying greens balanced it nicely and were sparse enough not to overwhelm it. It was excellently balanced. For us this meant: sunday, february 4, 2007 duck rillettes with savoy cabbage, mizuna salad and cornichon *** mussels and clams paysanne with jamon, green garlic, stinging nettles and white beans or roast leg of lamb with warm spinach salad, olives, anchovy and fried pumpkin persillade *** warm crepes with apple confit, crushed almonds and crème fraîche 40 dollars per person ------------------------------------------------- So, I was successfully food-wooed by Susan Mainzer.

properties.name: Jim says this is a good Thai place
properties.description: Posted by Choconancy2301 20th Ave NW Seattle , WA 98107

properties.name: Mondello Evening With Vivian
properties.description: Posted by Ourfounder2425 33rd Ave W, Seattle, 98199This is another location you\'ll see a lot on my map. Mondello is an Italian restaurant that is (mostly) family run, good prices, excellent food. Vivian, who is hesitant to compliment anything said last night, "I think their pasta is the best I\'ve ever had." Almost every time we go, the restaurant is nearly full. Last night it was overflowing with two large parties. We sat at the bar. When we left the office last night I said, "I need Stracciatella". It was all I wanted but the special breaded steak, I could not say no too. Vivian had the Spaghetti Alle Vonogle, which is on a very generous portion of clams cooked with a butter and herb sauce. The clams were very perfect. Vivian also makes the best Tiramisu I\'ve eaten, so I usually wince when she orders it. But Mondello\'s was wonderful. Light, not oversoaked, not too sweet.

properties.name: Nancy White
properties.description: Posted by ChoconancySeattle, Washington, USA

properties.name: Pair Restaurant: Zach's Birthday Dessert (International Zach Day 2007)
properties.description: Posted by Ourfounder My god! Four restaurants in one day! Today I went to 663, Bakery Nouveau, Chiang\'s Gourmet and Pair! These were spread between Seattle\'s International District, West Seattle, Maple Leaf and Ravenna neighborhoods. And I went to Costco and Daniel Smith\'s in there too. Add blogging this stuff and packing for my trip to Los Angeles tomorrow and it\'s been a busy day... After we ate Zach\'s Birthday Dinner at Chiang\'s Gourmet. We traveled over to Pair so Zach could eat their Chocolate Pot de Creme. I had the Flourless Chocolate Cake with some nifty soaked cherries (caitlin had this as well). Vivian had the Lemon Creme Brulee. Randy had the Apple tart. Eric didn\'t eat anything ... I think. Pair\'s desserts are wonderful, as is their main menu. I\'m sure we\'ll get back there so I can talk about their actual fare. The service at Pair is always friendly and borderline sensuous. The atmosphere is very romantic. For some reason, the lighting and the decor make everyone very attractive. I think Zach will be sending me pictures to post from the evening.

properties.name: Pleasing Pie at Serious Pie (pizza)
properties.description: Posted by Choconancy316 Virginia, Seattle, WA 98121My friend Karen and I made our annual pilgrimage to the NW Garden and Flower Show with an early evening dinner break at Tom Douglas\' new pizza joint, Serious Pie. We arrived at 5:15. By 6 the joint was packed. It is small, shared tables and a cozy feeling. The slate front of the metal woodfired oven is an impressive shot as you come in the door and the restaurant backs on to the Dahlia Bakery\'s bakery with glass windows. It was too late in the day for watching, but I\'ll come back for lunch to watch the bakers ate work. The pie? Sublime. Thin but sturdy crust, a little less chewy than my favorite point, but great flavor. We split a roasted beet salad and a caramelized onion, gorgonzola and rabe pizza - olive oil, no red sauce. It was rich, I could taste each ingredient. Our very nice waiter said "I you are hungry you should each get a pie." With salad, we were very happy with one (except for coveting our neigbors\' pies. I wanted just a bite to try the other pies!) The salad was yummy but could have used a bit more salt and pepper. The red beets were the best. The almost white beets had a great texture, but much less flavor. So I\'d go with the flavor over the visual appeal of the two colors of beets. It was lightly dressed in olive oil, a winey vinegar (not enough for my taste - I like the bite) and chopped mint. We were both pretty tired so we split a glass of wine - a nice pino grigio whose name I forget. I know, two middle aged women SPLITTING a glass of wine? Well, if we had both gotten one, we would have both finished our glasses and never made it through the flower show. Here\'s the kicker. Our waiter poured our wine into two half glasses. That was the capper to a very nice evening meal. Thanks waiter guy - you were the little bit that made a big difference.

properties.name: Quick Meal with Vivian
properties.description: Posted by OurfounderVivian has been working on a big chocolate order for the last few days. I am tired, climbing out of the limo from the airport, and coming into the house. "I can\'t let food contaminate the chocolate, where can we eat fast?" she says. I have eaten in 16 restaurants in four days and two states. I\'m tired. So we went up to Nikko\'s to have fast greek food. Quick Souvlaki. Then back home so Vivian could make orange infused and vanilla infused chocolates. And I can get some sleep.

properties.name: Theo Chocolate
properties.description: Posted by Choconancy3400 Phinney Ave. N. Seattle, WA 98103Made organic from the bean up in Fremont neighborhood of Seattle.

properties.name: Triple Door: Voices in Wartime Benefit Concert and Dinner with Friends
properties.description: Posted by Choconancy 216 Union St, Seattle, WAJim posted about the evening already, so I\'ll just add my rants and raves. I loved hearing Charlie Murphy sing on stage again. I was a fan and supporter of his band, Rumors of the Big Wave and was sad when the band split up. His voice has mellowed and taken on a new resonance and maturity that suited the songs he sang. And the drummer with his amazing drum/stool/thingie - oh, I want to play with one of those! The Doganauts (did I spell that right?) had some great musicians in the mix. I didn\'t dig all the songs, but the labor-of-love essense trumped that. Again, the musicianship in Rouge was top notch, while I was less engaged with the lead singer\'s presentation. It could be I was just getting tired as it was a long day. On the food side, the Triple Door serves from the Wild Ginger kitchen - at least that is my understanding. I loved our entrees. The lamb chops were nummy. The fragrant beef is one of my Wild Ginger favorites. But like upstairs at WG, the quality is really variable. (WG used to be a favorite restaurant to go to and to recommend to out of towners, but I don\'t any more. The service in the restaurant has always been terrific. I wish the same could be said for downstairs at the Triple Door.) Primarily, the appetizers were bland. We had a vegetarian Budda roll while we were waiting for the gang to show up. The dipping sauce was almost tasteless. They used to have a spicier sauce and a peanut sauce option. The squid was barely lukewarm and visually a mess on the plate. The roti was barely warm. Service was variable. At first our guy was attentive and helpful. Then it seemed like a major effort to get his attention. At the end of the evening, we had to flag a busser in the dark to get our bill. Oh, and the heartbreak, I was all set to have the dessert souffle of the night, mango coconut. But they only had five and they were sold out. Only had five? Gimmme a break. Dont\' tease me then send me home empty! Oi! As the designated driver in our family, I can\'t testify to the drinks, but my husband seemed to be enjoying the beers he tried!

properties.name: Update on Theo Chocolates
properties.description: Posted by Choconancy3400 Phinney Ave. N. Seattle, WA 98103I had the chance to take an out of towner to Theo\'s Fremont shop this week. They have moved up into the old "Community Living Room" space with a shop that is open during the week. (Before it was only on Sunday\'s). First, GENEROUS sampling. If you want to try their bars or nibble a piece of truffle, they will help you out. It\'s good business as it is hard to resist buying something to take home. I tried the cardomom caramel - sublime, and bought a Whiskey and a Coffee truffle to take home to my choco-hubby, along with some of their cacao nib toffee. Oh lordy, that\'s good stuff.

properties.name: Wow!  That was good!
properties.description: Posted by OurfounderVivian is on the hunt for the best chocolate in Seattle so she\'s knows what she\'s up against. Today we went to Bakery Nouveau in West Seattle and it was phenomenal! I had a strawberry crusted chocolate mousse with strawberry mousse in the center. It was shaped like a baseball. My god was it good. Nancy White, are you listening?
